1. Switch cron sessionTarget to a persistent session key (e.g. 'braids:orchestrator')
2. Configure aggressive compaction for that session so the transcript stays small after each run
3. Orchestrator.md stays in system prompt context ‚Äî no need to re-read each tick
4. Document how to configure this in SKILL.md

The session should compact after each run summarizing what was spawned/idled. Combined with braids-3m6 (3-tool-call flow), each run becomes very lightweight.

title: Pass session labels to orch-run CLI for concurrency-aware spawn decisions
description:
Currently braids orch-run ignores active workers, defaulting worker counts to 0. The orchestrator agent must call sessions_list, parse labels, check bead status per session (expensive), and do its own concurrency filtering ‚Äî burning many tokens and causing timeouts.

Fix: Accept active session labels as CLI input so the CLI handles concurrency checking in pure Clojure.

Interface (proposed):
  braids orch-run --sessions 'project:zaap:abc project:braids:xyz'

The CLI then:
1. Parses the label list to extract slug and bead-id per session
2. Checks bead status for each (bd show) to detect zombies (closed bead = zombie)
3. Counts healthy workers per project
4. Filters spawn list to respect max-workers per project

Updated orchestrator flow becomes just 3 tool calls:
1. sessions_list ‚Üí extract project: labels
2. braids orch-run --sessions <labels> ‚Üí filtered spawn list
3. sessions_spawn for each entry

Also update orchestrator.md to reflect the new simplified flow.

title: Refine disable logic: blocked beads should not keep orchestrator alive
description:
Current behavior after braids-914: orchestrator stays alive if any active iteration has open (non-closed) beads. But BLOCKED beads are effectively stuck ‚Äî they need human intervention, not more orchestrator polling.

Correct logic:
- Only count beads that are actually workable (open/in-progress but NOT blocked) toward 'keep alive'
- If all remaining open beads are blocked, treat same as no ready beads ‚Üí disable_cron: true
- This mirrors bd ready behavior: blocked beads don't show as ready

Implementation: in orch.clj, when checking open-beads, filter out beads with status 'blocked'. Only non-blocked open beads should keep the cron alive.

title: Refine orchestrator disable logic: only stay alive if active iterations have open beads
description:
Current behavior (braids-q6p fix): disable_cron:false whenever reason is 'no-ready-beads', assuming active iterations exist. Too broad ‚Äî keeps cron alive even when active iterations have zero open beads (e.g. empty iteration, all beads closed/blocked).

Correct logic:
- disable_cron: true when no active iterations exist
- disable_cron: true when all active iterations have no open (non-closed) beads  
- disable_cron: false when at least one active iteration has open beads

Implementation: in orch.clj, after collecting active projects/iterations, check bd list (or bd ready --include-blocked) per project to see if any open beads exist. If none across all projects, set disable_cron: true regardless of idle reason.

This handles the edge case where an iteration is active but empty or fully blocked with no hope of becoming ready.

Solution: Replace bd boilerplate AGENTS.md with a project-aware version that:
- Points to ~/.openclaw/skills/projects/references/worker.md as the worker convention doc
- Also includes the public URL (clawhub.com or GitHub) for worker.md so agents on machines without OpenClaw installed can still follow conventions
- Contains project-specific context (bd quick ref, git push requirements) in minimal form
- Serves as THE single boot file any agent reads when entering a project

The skill should generate this AGENTS.md during project creation (bd init or project setup). Orchestrator spawn message can be simplified since AGENTS.md handles onboarding.

Eliminates duplication between bd AGENTS.md and worker.md. Any entry point ‚Äî orchestrator, manual, external ‚Äî gets full guidance.

- deliverable file (.braids/iterations/007/p0e-websocket-handshake.md)
- bead-complete notification

Fix required:
1. Update orchestrator.md to include agentId: 'scrapper' in sessions_spawn calls
2. OR update braids orch-run CLI to output agentId in spawn JSON
3. OR add project-level worker agent configuration

This ensures workers follow the full braids protocol (claim, notify, work, deliverable, commit, notify) instead of just ad-hoc implementation.

title: Standardize iteration status format and add orchestrator format tolerance

comments.author: micahmartin
comments.text: Workers reformatted iteration 006 status from 'Status: active' to '- **Status:** active' (markdown bold + list prefix). The orchestrator failed to recognize this as active for 12+ hours, burning tokens on idle backoff cycles. Fix: (1) Document the exact required format in orchestrator.md and worker.md, (2) Add a speclj spec that validates iteration status format, (3) Consider making the orchestrator instructions more explicit about format matching.

title: Move PROJECT.md and iterations/ into .project/ directory to reduce root clutter

comments.author: micahmartin
comments.text: Move PROJECT.md and iterations/ into .project/ so the project root stays clean for actual project content. AGENTS.md stays at root (agent entry point convention). Update all references in SKILL.md, worker.md, orchestrator.md, CONTRACTS.md, project-creation.md, migration.md, and specs. This is a breaking change ‚Äî existing projects will need migration. Document the migration path. This project (projects-skill) should be migrated as part of the bead.

title: Move worker prompt out of CLI and into orchestrator.md
description:
The braids CLI (orch.clj) currently hardcodes the worker prompt in worker-instruction and includes it in the orch-run JSON output. This is the wrong responsibility ‚Äî the CLI should not know about prompt content.

Fix:
1. Remove worker-instruction and format-spawn-msg from orch.clj
2. orch-run spawn entries should only include the structural data needed: project path, bead id, iteration, channel, label, agentId, timeouts
3. The orchestrator.md should define the worker prompt template and instruct the orchestrator agent to construct the task message itself before calling sessions_spawn

The orchestrator already reads orchestrator.md and knows how to spawn ‚Äî it should own the prompt content, not the CLI.

Updated spawn entry from CLI (no task field):
{
  'project': '~/Projects/braids',
  'bead': 'braids-abc',
  'iteration': '018',
  'channel': '1471680593497554998',
  'label': 'project:braids:braids-abc',
  'agentId': 'scrapper',
  'runTimeoutSeconds': 3600,
  'cleanup': 'delete',
  'thinking': 'low'
}

orchestrator.md defines the task template and the agent fills it in.

title: Standardize terminology: use 'worker' not 'agent' throughout docs
description: Replace all references to 'agent' (when referring to spawned sessions doing project work) with 'worker'. Update SKILL.md, references/worker.md, PROJECT.md format (MaxAgents -> MaxWorkers), and any other docs. 'Worker' = an isolated session spawned to execute project tasks.

title: Fix Homebrew braids path resolution
acceptance_criteria: Homebrew-installed braids finds active iterations and ready beads correctly. Fix path resolution issues that cause 'No active iteration found' and 'No ready beads' when iterations and beads exist. Ensure consistency with development version behavior.

title: Fix orchestrator self-disable: stay enabled while active iterations exist
description:
The orchestrator currently disables itself whenever there are no ready beads (bd ready returns empty). This is too aggressive ‚Äî it should only disable when there are no active iterations across all projects.

The correct logic:
- Disable: no active iterations exist (nothing could ever become ready)
- Stay enabled: active iterations exist, even if no beads are ready right now (beads may become unblocked)

The orch-tick/orch-run CLI output includes the disable_cron flag. This flag should only be true when there are truly no active iterations, not just when no beads are currently ready.

Fix in src/braids/orch.clj ‚Äî the idle reason 'no-ready-beads' should NOT trigger disable_cron. Only 'no-active-iterations' should.

comments.author: micahmartin

It must NOT edit project files (SKILL.md, worker.md, orchestrator.md, PROJECT.md, CONTRACTS.md, etc.) directly. All file changes go through beads assigned to workers. title: Prevent duplicate iteration-complete notifications ‚Äî guard against race condition

comments.author: micahmartin
comments.text: When multiple workers finish beads around the same time, each checks bd ready, sees no open beads, and sends an iteration-complete notification. Fix: worker should check ITERATION.md status before announcing ‚Äî if it's already 'complete', skip the notification. The first worker to mark it complete wins; others see it's already done and stay quiet.

comments.author: micahmartin

title: Cron worker is orchestrator only ‚Äî spawns workers, does no bead work
description: The cron worker should ONLY: 1) read registry, 2) check active iterations, 3) count running workers vs MaxWorkers, 4) spawn async sessions (sessions_spawn) for beads, 5) sleep. It must NOT do any bead work itself. All bead work happens in spawned worker sessions. Update worker.md and cron prompt.

title: Optimize orchestrator: reduce zombie detection overhead
description:
The orchestrator is timing out (300s) because zombie detection is expensive ‚Äî it calls 'bd show <id>' for every active session label to check if the bead is closed. With multiple projects and sessions this blows the time budget before any workers get spawned.

Fix options:
1. Make zombie detection optional or lazy ‚Äî skip it if sessions_list shows no project: labeled sessions
2. Batch the bead status checks (bd list instead of individual bd show calls)
3. Move zombie detection to a separate lightweight pass
4. Simplify criteria ‚Äî only check session status (completed/failed/stopped), skip the bead-closed check

Goal: orchestrator should complete in under 60s even with many active projects.
